mn128:1.1.comm: This discourse offers a unique insight into the Buddha’s own meditative development. The “corruptions” of the title are the subtle mental flaws that undermine meditation when it is on the brink of absorption. | This discourse and MN 31 appear to be influenced by Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3, a famous dialogue where an unusually reluctant Yājñavalkya is repeatedly pressed by King Janaka to reveal the true nature of a person’s light.

mn128:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
mn128:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

mn128:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kosambiyaṃ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti.
mn128:2.1.eng: Now at that time the mendicants of Kosambī were fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
mn128:2.1.comm: This is in reference to the notorious quarrel at Kosambī, also referred to at MN 48:2.1. The events are detailed in the Vinaya at Kd 10.

mn128:3.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn128:3.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and told him what was happening, adding:

mn128:3.2.pli: “idha, bhante, kosambiyaṃ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti.

mn128:3.3.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
mn128:3.3.eng: “Please, sir go to those mendicants out of sympathy.”

mn128:3.4.comm: While both here and at MN 48 we see the Buddha intervening to settle the conflict, here he goes to them, while there he summons them to him; and the ensuing course of the sutta is quite different.

mn128:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
mn128:4.1.eng: Then the Buddha went up to those mendicants and said,

mn128:4.2.pli: “alaṃ, bhikkhave, mā bhaṇḍanaṃ, mā kalahaṃ, mā viggahaṃ, mā vivādan”ti.
mn128:4.2.eng: “Enough, mendicants! Stop fighting, quarreling, and disputing.”

mn128:4.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn128:4.3.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

mn128:4.5.eng: Let the Buddha, the Lord of the Dhamma,

mn128:4.6.pli: appossukko, bhante, bhagavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ anuyutto viharatu;
mn128:4.6.eng: remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in this life.

mn128:4.7.pli: mayametena bhaṇḍanena kalahena viggahena vivādena paññāyissāmā”ti.
mn128:4.7.eng: We will be known for this fighting, quarreling, arguing, and disputing.”

mn128:4.8.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā te bhikkhū etadavoca:

mn128:4.9.pli: “alaṃ, bhikkhave, mā bhaṇḍanaṃ, mā kalahaṃ, mā viggahaṃ, mā vivādan”ti.

mn128:4.10.pli: Dutiyampi kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

mn128:4.13.pli: appossukko, bhante, bhagavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ anuyutto viharatu;

mn128:4.14.pli: mayametena bhaṇḍanena kalahena viggahena vivādena paññāyissāmā”ti.

mn128:4.15.pli: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
mn128:4.15.eng: and a third time the Buddha said to those mendicants,

mn128:4.16.pli: “alaṃ, bhikkhave, mā bhaṇḍanaṃ, mā kalahaṃ, mā viggahaṃ, mā vivādan”ti.
mn128:4.16.eng: “Enough, mendicants! Stop fighting, quarreling, and disputing.”

mn128:4.17.pli: Tatiyampi kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn128:4.17.eng: For a third time that mendicant said to the Buddha,

mn128:4.19.eng: Let the Buddha, the Lord of the Dhamma,

mn128:4.20.pli: appossukko, bhante, bhagavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ anuyutto viharatu;
mn128:4.20.eng: remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in this life.

mn128:4.21.pli: mayametena bhaṇḍanena kalahena viggahena vivādena paññāyissāmā”ti.
mn128:4.21.eng: We will be known for this fighting, quarreling, arguing, and disputing.”

mn128:5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kosambiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn128:5.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kosambī for alms.

mn128:5.2.pli: Kosambiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya ṭhitakova imā gāthā abhāsi:
mn128:5.2.eng: After the meal, on his return from almsround, he set his lodgings in order. Taking his bowl and robe, he recited these verses while standing right there:

mn128:6.1.comm: These verses are also found in the Vinaya account at Kd 10:3.1.3 and the Kosambiya Jātaka at Ja 428:1.1.

mn128:6.2.eng: yet no-one thinks that they’re the fool.

mn128:6.4.eng: they think no better of the other.

mn128:6.6.eng: they talk, their words out of bounds.

mn128:6.7.eng: They blab at will, their mouths agape,

mn128:6.8.eng: and not one knows what leads them on.

mn128:6.9.comm: These four verses are shared with Dhp 3–6.

mn128:6.10.eng: They beat me, they robbed me!’

mn128:6.11.eng: For those bearing such a grudge,

mn128:6.12.eng: hatred is never laid to rest.

mn128:6.14.eng: They beat me, they robbed me!’

mn128:6.15.eng: For those who bear no such grudge,

mn128:6.19.eng: it’s laid to rest by love:

mn128:6.21.comm: This verse is found in the same context at Dhp 6, and in different contexts in Thag 4.3:1.1 and Thag 8.1:5.1.

mn128:6.22.eng: let us, who do understand this,
mn128:6.22.comm: Yamāmese is reflexive first person plural imperative of yamati, “let us restrain ourselves”, cf. SN 10.6:3.1: pāṇesu ca saṁyamāmase (“Let us restrain ourselves regarding living creatures”).

mn128:6.24.eng: for that is how conflicts are laid to rest.

mn128:6.25.eng: Breakers of bones and takers of life,

mn128:6.30.eng: If you find an alert companion,

mn128:6.31.eng: an attentive friend to live happily together,

mn128:6.33.eng: wander with them, joyful and mindful.

mn128:6.34.eng: If you find no alert companion,

mn128:6.35.eng: no attentive friend to live happily together,

mn128:6.36.eng: then, like a king who flees his conquered realm,

mn128:6.37.eng: wander alone like a tusker in the wilds.

mn128:6.40.pli: Eko care na ca pāpāni kayirā,
mn128:6.40.eng: Wander alone and do no wrong,

mn128:6.41.eng: at ease like a tusker in the wilds.”

mn128:7.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā ṭhitakova imā gāthā bhāsitvā yena bālakaloṇakāragāmo tenupasaṅkami.
mn128:7.1.eng: After speaking these verses while standing, the Buddha went to the village of the child salt-miners,
mn128:7.1.comm: “Child salt-miners” is bālakaloṇakāra (cf. loṇakāradārako at AN 4.188:5.3). Children are used to mine salt in India to this day.

mn128:7.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā bhagu bālakaloṇakāragāme viharati.
mn128:7.2.eng: where Venerable Bhagu was staying at the time.
mn128:7.2.comm: Bhagu was a leading Sakyan who went forth along with Bhaddiya, Anuruddha, Ānanda, Kimbila, Devadatta, and Upāli (Kd 17:1.4.1). He is known from his ardent striving described in his verses at Thag 4.2, and is listed with other renowned mendicants at MN 68:2.2. | After the conflict at Kosambī, the Buddha sought the company of his fellow Sakyans; first Bhagu, then the three Sakyans below. | Another Bhagu was one of the ancient Vedic seers, while yet another was a contemporary of Sāṇavāsī around the time of the Second Council (Kd 8:24.6.6).

mn128:7.3.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā bhagu bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn128:7.3.eng: Bhagu saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,

mn128:7.4.pli: Disvāna āsanaṃ paññapesi udakañca pādānaṃ dhovanaṃ.
mn128:7.4.eng: so he spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet.

mn128:7.5.eng: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,

mn128:7.7.pli: Āyasmāpi kho bhagu bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn128:7.7.eng: Bhagu bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

mn128:7.8.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ bhaguṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

mn128:7.9.pli: “kacci, bhikkhu, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci piṇḍakena na kilamasī”ti?
mn128:7.9.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”

mn128:7.10.pli: “Khamanīyaṃ bhagavā, yāpanīyaṃ bhagavā, na cāhaṃ, bhante, piṇḍakena kilamāmī”ti.
mn128:7.10.eng: “I’m keeping well, Blessed One; I’m all right. And I’m having no trouble getting almsfood.”

mn128:7.11.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ bhaguṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena pācīnavaṃsadāyo tenupasaṅkami.
mn128:7.11.eng: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Bhagu with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and set out for the Park of the East-Raftered Hall.

mn128:8.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo pācīnavaṃsadāye viharanti.
mn128:8.1.eng: Now at that time the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila were staying in the Park of the East-Raftered Hall.
mn128:8.1.comm: This park was in Ceti, not far from Kosambī. A Prācīnavaṁśa was a hall or shed built for the ritual, with bamboo (vaṁśa) rafters running easterly (prācīna; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.1.1.6 and Eggeling’s note). | Apart from the setting, the following passage is identical with MN 31:2.1ff., down as far as the discussion on meditation; see that sutta for notes. The current sutta is the original narrative context (see note on MN 31:6.1).

mn128:8.2.pli: Addasā kho dāyapālo bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn128:8.2.eng: The park keeper saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
mn128:8.2.comm: The park keeper was evidently not Buddhist, as he was responsible for a Vedic ritual site.

mn128:8.4.comm: MS and BJT read mahāsamaṇa here, whereas PTS and parallel passages at MN 31:3.4 and Kd 10:4.2.3 have simply samaṇa. Mahāsamaṇa (“great ascetic”) is a rare epithet of the Buddha found mainly in the Vinaya. It is unlikely the park keeper would have kept him out knowing who he really was.

mn128:8.5.eng: There are three gentlemen staying here whose nature is to desire only the self.

mn128:9.1.pli: Assosi kho āyasmā anuruddho dāyapālassa bhagavatā saddhiṃ mantayamānassa.
mn128:9.1.eng: Anuruddha heard the park keeper conversing with the Buddha,

mn128:9.3.eng: “Don’t keep the Buddha out, good park keeper!

mn128:9.4.eng: Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived.”

mn128:10.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho yenāyasmā ca nandiyo yenāyasmā ca kimilo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantañca nandiyaṃ āyasmantañca kimilaṃ etadavoca:
mn128:10.1.eng: Then Anuruddha went to Nandiya and Kimbila, and said to them,

mn128:10.2.eng: “Come forth, venerables, come forth! Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived!”

mn128:10.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo bhagavantaṃ paccuggantvā
mn128:10.3.eng: Then Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila came out to greet the Buddha.

mn128:10.4.pli: eko bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ paṭiggahesi, eko āsanaṃ paññapesi, eko pādodakaṃ upaṭṭhapesi.
mn128:10.4.eng: One received his bowl and robe, one spread out a seat, and one set out water for washing his feet.

mn128:10.5.eng: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out

mn128:10.7.pli: Tepi kho āyasmanto bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
mn128:10.7.eng: Those venerables bowed and sat down to one side.

mn128:10.8.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

mn128:10.9.pli: “kacci vo, anuruddhā, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci piṇḍakena na kilamathā”ti?
mn128:10.9.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, Anuruddha and friends; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”

mn128:10.10.pli: “Khamanīyaṃ bhagavā, yāpanīyaṃ bhagavā, na ca mayaṃ, bhante, piṇḍakena kilamāmā”ti.
mn128:10.10.eng: “We’re keeping well, Blessed One; we’re all right. And we’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”

mn128:11.1.pli: “Kacci pana vo, anuruddhā, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharathā”ti?
mn128:11.1.eng: “I hope you’re living in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes?”

mn128:11.2.pli: “Taggha mayaṃ, bhante, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharāmā”ti.
mn128:11.2.eng: “Indeed, sir, we live in harmony as you say.”

mn128:11.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tumhe, anuruddhā, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharathā”ti?
mn128:11.3.eng: “But how do you live this way?”

mn128:12.3.eng: to live together with spiritual companions such as these.’

mn128:12.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, imesu āyasmantesu mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca,
mn128:12.4.eng: I consistently treat these venerables with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.

mn128:12.5.pli: mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca,

mn128:12.6.pli: mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca.

mn128:12.8.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sakaṃ cittaṃ nikkhipitvā imesaṃyeva āyasmantānaṃ cittassa vasena vatteyyan’ti.
mn128:12.8.eng: ‘Why don’t I set aside my own ideas and just go along with these venerables’ ideas?’

mn128:12.9.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, sakaṃ cittaṃ nikkhipitvā imesaṃyeva āyasmantānaṃ cittassa vasena vattāmi.

mn128:12.10.pli: Nānā hi kho no, bhante, kāyā, ekañca pana maññe cittan”ti.
mn128:12.10.eng: Though we’re different in body, sir, we’re one in mind, it seems to me.”

mn128:12.11.eng: And the venerables Nandiya and Kimbila spoke likewise, and they added:

mn128:12.16.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, imesu āyasmantesu mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca,

mn128:12.17.pli: mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca,

mn128:12.18.pli: mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca.

mn128:12.20.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sakaṃ cittaṃ nikkhipitvā imesaṃyeva āyasmantānaṃ cittassa vasena vatteyyan’ti.

mn128:12.21.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, sakaṃ cittaṃ nikkhipitvā imesaṃyeva āyasmantānaṃ cittassa vasena vattāmi.

mn128:12.22.pli: Nānā hi kho no, bhante, kāyā, ekañca pana maññe cittanti.

mn128:12.23.pli: Evaṃ kho mayaṃ, bhante, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharāmā”ti.
mn128:12.23.eng: “That’s how we live in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.”

mn128:13.2.pli: Kacci pana vo, anuruddhā, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharathā”ti?
mn128:13.2.eng: But I hope you’re living diligently, keen, and resolute?”

mn128:14.1.pli: “Taggha mayaṃ, bhante, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharāmā”ti.

mn128:14.2.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tumhe, anuruddhā, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharathā”ti?
mn128:14.2.eng: “But how do you live this way?”

mn128:14.3.pli: “Idha, bhante, amhākaṃ yo paṭhamaṃ gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamati, so āsanāni paññapeti, pānīyaṃ paribhojanīyaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti, avakkārapātiṃ upaṭṭhāpeti.
mn128:14.3.eng: “In this case, sir, whoever returns first from almsround prepares the seats, and puts out the drinking water and the rubbish bin.

mn128:14.4.pli: Yo pacchā gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamati—sace hoti bhuttāvaseso, sace ākaṅkhati, bhuñjati; no ce ākaṅkhati, appaharite vā chaḍḍeti apāṇake vā udake opilāpeti—
mn128:14.4.eng: If there’s anything left over, whoever returns last eats it if they like. Otherwise they throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.

mn128:14.5.pli: so āsanāni paṭisāmeti, pānīyaṃ paribhojanīyaṃ paṭisāmeti, avakkārapātiṃ dhovitvā paṭisāmeti, bhattaggaṃ sammajjati.
mn128:14.5.eng: Then they put away the seats, drinking water, and rubbish bin, and sweep the refectory.

mn128:14.6.pli: Yo passati pānīyaghaṭaṃ vā paribhojanīyaghaṭaṃ vā vaccaghaṭaṃ vā rittaṃ tucchaṃ so upaṭṭhāpeti.
mn128:14.6.eng: If someone sees that the pot of water for washing, drinking, or the toilet is empty they set it up.

mn128:14.7.pli: Sacassa hoti avisayhaṃ, hatthavikārena dutiyaṃ āmantetvā hatthavilaṅghakena upaṭṭhāpema, na tveva mayaṃ, bhante, tappaccayā vācaṃ bhindāma.
mn128:14.7.eng: If he can’t do it, he summons another with a wave of the hand, and they set it up by lending each other a hand to lift. But we don’t break into speech for that reason.
mn128:14.7.comm: For hatthavilaṅghaka (“lending a hand up”) see MN 125:9.2.

mn128:14.8.pli: Pañcāhikaṃ kho pana mayaṃ, bhante, sabbarattiṃ dhammiyā kathāya sannisīdāma.
mn128:14.8.eng: And every five days we sit together for the whole night and discuss the teachings.

mn128:14.9.pli: Evaṃ kho mayaṃ, bhante, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharāmā”ti.
mn128:14.9.eng: That’s how we live diligently, keen, and resolute.”

mn128:15.2.pli: Atthi pana vo, anuruddhā, evaṃ appamattānaṃ ātāpīnaṃ pahitattānaṃ viharataṃ uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
mn128:15.2.eng: But as you live diligently like this, have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation?”
mn128:15.2.comm: As at MN 31:10.3ff., Anuruddha must be prodded to reveal the full extent of his meditation prowess. The form of both suttas parallels Yājñavalkya’s reticence to answer Janaka. In addition, the theme also echoes the Upaniṣad, for Janaka asks what is a person’s light (kiṁjyotirayaṁ puruṣa, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.2). Yājñavalkya answers that it is simply the sun. When pressed further, he admits it might be the moon, then fire, or even speech, for you can make it home in the dark when someone is calling. All these things—sun, moon, fire, speech—are worshipped in the Vedic tradition as external manifestations of divinity. He only reluctantly admits that a person’s true light is their Self, made of consciousness, the light in the heart. This is the same Self referred to above in the phrase, “whose nature is to desire only the self”. | The Vedantic commentator Śaṅkara, on a verse of the same chapter (4.3.7), discusses at length Buddhist objections to his doctrine. Thus the Buddhist text looks back to the Upaniṣad, while the commentary to that same Upaniṣad looks to Buddhism.

mn128:15.3.pli: “Idha mayaṃ, bhante, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharantā obhāsañceva sañjānāma dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:15.3.eng: “Well, sir, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, we perceive both light and vision of forms.
mn128:15.3.comm: The key terms here are “perceive” (sañjānāma), “light” (obhāsa), and “vision of forms” (dassanañca rūpānaṁ). Variations of these are common terms for the visions seen in meditation (eg. DN 9:14.2, MN 77:22.2, MN 121:5.4). The “light” is the radiance that indicates freedom from defilements, while the “forms” may be the various phenomena that one in such a meditation might see. In particular this refers to the power of clairvoyance (dibbacakkhu), in which Anuruddha was later declared foremost (AN 1.192:1.1). See the discussion in the previous sutta (MN 127:10.1) and also eg. MN 32:6.6, SN 9.6:1.2 AN 3.130:1.3, and AN 8.46:1.3.

mn128:15.4.pli: So kho pana no obhāso nacirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ;
mn128:15.4.eng: But before long the light and the vision of forms vanish.

mn128:15.5.eng: We haven’t worked out the basis of that.”
mn128:15.5.comm: Below, the Buddha investigates by way of “cause and reason” (MN 128:16.5), hence the commentary explains nimitta here as “basis” (kāraṇa; for similar senses see MN 12:23.1, SN 48.40:1.6, AN 3.102:1.2). | Confusingly, in the previous sentence we have “light and vision of forms”, but this is not nimitta, which does not have this meaning in early texts. For related contexts, see DN 11:80.12, DN 33:1.9.27, MN 5:6.1, MN 20:2.1, MN 36:45.6, MN 44:12.3, AN 3.19:2.3, AN 4.14:4.2, AN 6.27:7.1, and AN 9.35:1.11. | Anuruddha learned his lesson, for at MN 68:6.2 he explains how hindrances prevent absorption.

mn128:16.1.pli: “Taṃ kho pana vo, anuruddhā, nimittaṃ paṭivijjhitabbaṃ.
mn128:16.1.eng: “Well, you should work out the basis of that.

mn128:16.2.pli: Ahampi sudaṃ, anuruddhā, pubbeva sambodhā anabhisambuddho bodhisattova samāno obhāsañceva sañjānāmi dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:16.2.eng: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too perceived light and vision of forms.

mn128:16.3.pli: So kho pana me obhāso nacirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:16.3.eng: But before long my light and vision of forms vanished.
mn128:16.3.comm: This refers to a stage in the development of meditation when immersion is not properly consolidated. It is a delicate phase, where familiar hindrances appear in subtle ways, which can nonetheless be an obstacle for absorption. Below I give my understanding of these meditation issues and how to deal with them.

mn128:16.5.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena me obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānan’ti?
mn128:16.5.eng: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why my light and vision of forms vanish?’

mn128:16.7.pli: ‘vicikicchā kho me udapādi, vicikicchādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:16.7.eng: ‘Doubt arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
mn128:16.7.comm: When immersion is not consolidated, even the slightest uncertainty as to how to proceed can disturb the meditation. Doubt can also arise regarding whether the visions seen in meditation are real. This can be counteracted by determining one’s meditation at the beginning. | These three sentences use grammatical tense very precisely: an event is recalled (in past tense); a timeless principle is inferred (in present tense); and a resolution is made (in future tense).

mn128:16.8.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:16.8.eng: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.

mn128:16.9.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissatī’ti.
mn128:16.9.eng: I’ll make sure that doubt will not arise in me again.’

mn128:17.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, anuruddhā, appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañceva sañjānāmi dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:17.1.eng: While meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, I perceived light and vision of forms.

mn128:17.2.pli: So kho pana me obhāso nacirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:17.2.eng: But before long my light and vision of forms vanished.

mn128:17.4.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena me obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānan’ti?
mn128:17.4.eng: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why my light and vision of forms vanish?’

mn128:17.6.pli: ‘amanasikāro kho me udapādi, amanasikārādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:17.6.eng: ‘Loss of focus arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
mn128:17.6.comm: The mind drifts from the meditation. At this subtle level, the mind may not be wandering or lost, but merely focusing imprecisely.

mn128:17.7.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:17.7.eng: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.

mn128:17.8.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro’ti.
mn128:17.8.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus will arise in me again.’

mn128:18.3.pli: ‘thinamiddhaṃ kho me udapādi, thinamiddhādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:18.3.comm: Practicing to this level takes time, and any meditator will experience drowsiness at some point, even if it is merely a lack of fully clear energy. It is counteracted by rapture (pīti), which uplifts and inspires the mind.

mn128:18.4.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

mn128:18.5.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhan’ti.
mn128:18.5.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness will arise in me again.’

mn128:19.3.pli: ‘chambhitattaṃ kho me udapādi, chambhitattādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:19.3.eng: ‘Terror arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.

mn128:19.4.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:19.4.eng: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.

mn128:19.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso addhānamaggappaṭipanno, tassa ubhatopasse vaṭṭakā uppateyyuṃ, tassa tatonidānaṃ chambhitattaṃ uppajjeyya;
mn128:19.5.eng: Suppose a person was traveling along a road, and killers were to spring out at them from both sides. They’d feel terrified because of that.
mn128:19.5.comm: While “terror” might feel like an overly-strong rendering for chambhitatta in this context, this example shows what it means. At this point the mind is amplified, so that even small reactions can quickly get out of hand. The Buddha explains more about this point in his meditation at MN 4:20.1.

mn128:19.6.pli: evameva kho me, anuruddhā, chambhitattaṃ udapādi, chambhitattādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:19.6.eng: In the same way, terror arose in me …

mn128:19.7.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

mn128:19.8.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattan’ti.
mn128:19.8.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror will arise in me again.’

mn128:20.3.pli: ‘uppilaṃ kho me udapādi, uppilādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:20.3.eng: ‘Elation arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
mn128:20.3.comm: This can happen when the mind is starting to coalesce, and one is excited that absorption is near. To address this, a meditator might reflect on the importance of patience, and focus more on developing tranquility in the fundamental stages of meditation.

mn128:20.4.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:20.4.eng: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.

mn128:20.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso ekaṃ nidhimukhaṃ gavesanto sakideva pañcanidhimukhāni adhigaccheyya, tassa tatonidānaṃ uppilaṃ uppajjeyya;
mn128:20.5.eng: Suppose a person was looking for the entrance to a treasure trove. And all at once they’d come across five entrances! They’d feel excited because of that.
mn128:20.5.comm: For “treasure trove” in meditation, compare MN 52 = AN 11.16.

mn128:20.6.pli: evameva kho me, anuruddhā, uppilaṃ udapādi, uppilādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:20.6.eng: In the same way, elation arose in me …

mn128:20.7.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

mn128:20.8.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattaṃ, na uppilan’ti.
mn128:20.8.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation will arise in me again.’

mn128:21.3.pli: ‘duṭṭhullaṃ kho me udapādi, duṭṭhullādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:21.3.comm: All meditators experience discomfort when sitting for long periods of time. To deal with this, a meditator should first get as comfortable as they reasonably can, then develop pleasure in the body. Anuruddha overcame pain in the body through the four kinds of mindfulness meditation (SN 52.10:2.1).

mn128:21.4.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

mn128:21.5.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattaṃ, na uppilaṃ, na duṭṭhullan’ti.
mn128:21.5.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort will arise in me again.’

mn128:22.3.pli: ‘accāraddhavīriyaṃ kho me udapādi, accāraddhavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:22.3.eng: ‘Excessive energy arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
mn128:22.3.comm: Pushing too hard at the meditation, the body and mind can become over-wired with energy. To find balance, a meditator needs to relax and draw back from the meditation just a little.

mn128:22.4.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:22.4.eng: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.

mn128:22.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso ubhohi hatthehi vaṭṭakaṃ gāḷhaṃ gaṇheyya, so tattheva patameyya;
mn128:22.5.eng: Suppose a person was to grip a quail too tightly in their hands—it would die right there.

mn128:22.6.pli: evameva kho me, anuruddhā, accāraddhavīriyaṃ udapādi, accāraddhavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.

mn128:22.7.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

mn128:22.8.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattaṃ, na uppilaṃ, na duṭṭhullaṃ, na accāraddhavīriyan’ti.
mn128:22.8.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy will arise in me again.’

mn128:23.3.pli: ‘atilīnavīriyaṃ kho me udapādi, atilīnavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:23.3.eng: ‘Overly lax energy arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
mn128:23.3.comm: The opposite of the previous, here the mind subtly falls back from the meditation too far. They are not exactly drowsy, but the mind lacks the keenness to go deeper. In response, a meditator needs to apply the mind a little more strongly to the meditation.

mn128:23.4.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:23.4.eng: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.

mn128:23.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso vaṭṭakaṃ sithilaṃ gaṇheyya, so tassa hatthato uppateyya;
mn128:23.5.eng: Suppose a person was to grip a quail too loosely—it would fly out of their hands.

mn128:23.6.pli: evameva kho me, anuruddhā, atilīnavīriyaṃ udapādi, atilīnavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.

mn128:23.7.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

mn128:23.8.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattaṃ, na uppilaṃ, na duṭṭhullaṃ, na accāraddhavīriyaṃ, na atilīnavīriyan’ti.
mn128:23.8.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy nor overly lax energy will arise in me again.’

mn128:24.3.pli: ‘abhijappā kho me udapādi, abhijappādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:24.3.comm: The meditator yearns for higher spiritual realizations, as at Thag 19.1:16.1 or AN 4.159:6.7. This is a wholesome motivation, but at this point it can disturb the meditation.

mn128:24.4.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

mn128:24.5.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattaṃ, na uppilaṃ, na duṭṭhullaṃ, na accāraddhavīriyaṃ, na atilīnavīriyaṃ, na abhijappā’ti.
mn128:24.5.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy nor overly lax energy nor longing will arise in me again.’

mn128:25.3.pli: ‘nānattasaññā kho me udapādi, nānattasaññādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
mn128:25.3.comm: Diversity can arise through the activity of the senses, or through the variety of “forms” seen by the meditator. Either way, the mind must be settled to find true oneness.

mn128:25.4.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.

mn128:25.5.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattaṃ, na uppilaṃ, na duṭṭhullaṃ, na accāraddhavīriyaṃ, na atilīnavīriyaṃ, na abhijappā, na nānattasaññā’ti.
mn128:25.5.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy nor overly lax energy nor longing nor perception of diversity will arise in me again.’

mn128:26.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, anuruddhā, appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañceva sañjānāmi dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:26.1.eng: While meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, I perceived light and vision of forms.

mn128:26.2.pli: So kho pana me obhāso nacirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:26.2.eng: But before long my light and vision of forms vanished.

mn128:26.4.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena me obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānan’ti.
mn128:26.4.eng: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why my light and vision of forms vanish?’

mn128:26.6.pli: ‘atinijjhāyitattaṃ kho me rūpānaṃ udapādi, atinijjhāyitattādhikaraṇañca pana me rūpānaṃ samādhi cavi.
mn128:26.6.eng: ‘Excessive concentration on forms arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
mn128:26.6.comm: The “forms” seen in meditation can be enticing and fascinating, appearing as glimpses of other realms, impressions of the presence of beings, or images of past lives. If the meditator pays too much attention to them, they lose focus on the meditation itself.

mn128:26.7.pli: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
mn128:26.7.eng: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.

mn128:26.8.pli: Sohaṃ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṃ, na chambhitattaṃ, na uppilaṃ, na duṭṭhullaṃ, na accāraddhavīriyaṃ, na atilīnavīriyaṃ, na abhijappā, na nānattasaññā, na atinijjhāyitattaṃ rūpānan’ti.
mn128:26.8.eng: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy nor overly lax energy nor longing nor perception of diversity nor excessive concentration on forms will arise in me again.’

mn128:27.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, anuruddhā, ‘vicikicchā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā vicikicchaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,
mn128:27.1.eng: When I understood that doubt is a corruption of the mind, I gave it up.

mn128:27.2.pli: ‘amanasikāro cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā amanasikāraṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,
mn128:27.2.eng: When I understood that loss of focus,

mn128:27.3.pli: ‘thinamiddhaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā thinamiddhaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,

mn128:27.4.pli: ‘chambhitattaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā chambhitattaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,

mn128:27.5.pli: ‘uppilaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā uppilaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,

mn128:27.6.pli: ‘duṭṭhullaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā duṭṭhullaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,

mn128:27.7.pli: ‘accāraddhavīriyaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā accāraddhavīriyaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,

mn128:27.8.pli: ‘atilīnavīriyaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā atilīnavīriyaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,

mn128:27.9.pli: ‘abhijappā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā abhijappaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,

mn128:27.10.pli: ‘nānattasaññā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā nānattasaññaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ,

mn128:27.11.pli: ‘atinijjhāyitattaṃ rūpānaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā atinijjhāyitattaṃ rūpānaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahiṃ.
mn128:27.11.eng: and excessive concentration on forms are corruptions of the mind, I gave them up.

mn128:28.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, anuruddhā, appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañhi kho sañjānāmi, na ca rūpāni passāmi;
mn128:28.1.eng: While meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, I perceived light but did not see forms,

mn128:28.2.pli: rūpāni hi kho passāmi, na ca obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi:
mn128:28.2.eng: or I saw forms, but did not see light.

mn128:28.3.eng: And this went on for a whole night, a whole day, even a whole night and day.

mn128:28.5.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yvāhaṃ obhāsañhi kho sañjānāmi na ca rūpāni passāmi;
mn128:28.5.eng: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason for this?’

mn128:28.6.pli: rūpāni hi kho passāmi na ca obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi—

mn128:28.7.pli: kevalampi rattiṃ, kevalampi divaṃ, kevalampi rattindivan’ti.

mn128:28.9.pli: ‘yasmiñhi kho ahaṃ samaye rūpanimittaṃ amanasikaritvā obhāsanimittaṃ manasi karomi, obhāsañhi kho tasmiṃ samaye sañjānāmi, na ca rūpāni passāmi.
mn128:28.9.eng: ‘When I don’t focus on the basis of the forms, but focus on the basis of the light, then I perceive light and do not see forms.
mn128:28.9.comm: This shows how nimitta has a causal sense. Manasikāra (“focus”) is typically used of paying attention to causes.

mn128:28.10.pli: Yasmiṃ panāhaṃ samaye obhāsanimittaṃ amanasikaritvā rūpanimittaṃ manasi karomi, rūpāni hi kho tasmiṃ samaye passāmi na ca obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi—
mn128:28.10.eng: But when I don’t focus on the basis of the light, but focus on the basis of the forms, then I see forms and do not perceive light.

mn128:28.11.pli: kevalampi rattiṃ, kevalampi divaṃ, kevalampi rattindivan’ti.
mn128:28.11.eng: And this goes on for a whole night, a whole day, even a whole night and day.’

mn128:29.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, anuruddhā, appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto parittañceva obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi, parittāni ca rūpāni passāmi;
mn128:29.1.eng: While meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, I perceived limited light and saw limited forms,

mn128:29.2.pli: appamāṇañceva obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi, appamāṇāni ca rūpāni passāmi:
mn128:29.2.eng: or I perceived limitless light and saw limitless forms.

mn128:29.3.eng: And this went on for a whole night, a whole day, even a whole night and day.

mn128:29.5.pli: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yvāhaṃ parittañceva obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi, parittāni ca rūpāni passāmi;
mn128:29.5.eng: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason for this?’

mn128:29.6.pli: appamāṇañceva obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi, appamāṇāni ca rūpāni passāmi—

mn128:29.7.pli: kevalampi rattiṃ, kevalampi divaṃ, kevalampi rattindivan’ti.

mn128:29.9.pli: ‘yasmiṃ kho me samaye paritto samādhi hoti, parittaṃ me tasmiṃ samaye cakkhu hoti.
mn128:29.9.eng: ‘When my immersion is limited, then my vision is limited,

mn128:29.10.pli: Sohaṃ parittena cakkhunā parittañceva obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi, parittāni ca rūpāni passāmi.
mn128:29.10.eng: and with limited vision I perceive limited light and see limited forms.

mn128:29.11.pli: Yasmiṃ pana me samaye appamāṇo samādhi hoti, appamāṇaṃ me tasmiṃ samaye cakkhu hoti.
mn128:29.11.eng: But when my immersion is limitless, then my vision is limitless,

mn128:29.12.pli: Sohaṃ appamāṇena cakkhunā appamāṇañceva obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi, appamāṇāni ca rūpāni passāmi—
mn128:29.12.eng: and with limitless vision I perceive limitless light and see limitless forms.

mn128:29.13.pli: kevalampi rattiṃ, kevalampi divaṃ, kevalampi rattindivan’ti.
mn128:29.13.eng: And this goes on for a whole night, a whole day, even a whole night and day.’

mn128:30.1.pli: Yato kho me, anuruddhā, ‘vicikicchā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā vicikicchā cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.2.pli: ‘amanasikāro cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā amanasikāro cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.3.pli: ‘thinamiddhaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā thinamiddhaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.4.pli: ‘chambhitattaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā chambhitattaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.5.pli: ‘uppilaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā uppilaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.6.pli: ‘duṭṭhullaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā duṭṭhullaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.7.pli: ‘accāraddhavīriyaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā accāraddhavīriyaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.8.pli: ‘atilīnavīriyaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā atilīnavīriyaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.9.pli: ‘abhijappā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā abhijappā cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.10.pli: ‘nānattasaññā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā nānattasaññā cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,

mn128:30.11.pli: ‘atinijjhāyitattaṃ rūpānaṃ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā atinijjhāyitattaṃ rūpānaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi.
mn128:30.11.eng: and excessive concentration on forms are corruptions of the mind, I had given them up.

mn128:31.2.pli: ‘ye kho me cittassa upakkilesā te me pahīnā.

mn128:31.3.eng: Now let me develop immersion in three ways.’

mn128:31.4.pli: So kho ahaṃ, anuruddhā, savitakkampi savicāraṃ samādhiṃ bhāvesiṃ, avitakkampi vicāramattaṃ samādhiṃ bhāvesiṃ, avitakkampi avicāraṃ samādhiṃ bhāvesiṃ, sappītikampi samādhiṃ bhāvesiṃ, nippītikampi samādhiṃ bhāvesiṃ, sātasahagatampi samādhiṃ bhāvesiṃ, upekkhāsahagatampi samādhiṃ bhāvesiṃ.
mn128:31.4.eng: I developed immersion while placing the mind and keeping it connected; without placing the mind, merely keeping it connected; without placing the mind or keeping it connected; with rapture; without rapture; with pleasure; with equanimity.
mn128:31.4.comm: This threefold presentation of the process of absorption focuses on vitakka (“placing the mind”) and vicāra (“keeping it connected”), looking closely at how they cease (see also DN 33:1.10.121, DN 34:1.4.7, SN 43.3:1.2, and AN 8.63:3.1). The standard jhāna formula focuses more on the refinement of feelings, from which perspective the first two stages of immersion here fall under the “rapture and bliss born of seclusion”, while only the third qualifies as “rapture and bliss born of immersion”. Thus Analayo describes the two descriptions as “complementary perspectives on the same process of deepening concentration” (Comparative Study, vol. ii, pg. 739, note 263).

mn128:32.1.pli: Yato kho me, anuruddhā, savitakkopi savicāro samādhi bhāvito ahosi, avitakkopi vicāramatto samādhi bhāvito ahosi, avitakkopi avicāro samādhi bhāvito ahosi, sappītikopi samādhi bhāvito ahosi, nippītikopi samādhi bhāvito ahosi, sātasahagatopi samādhi bhāvito ahosi, upekkhāsahagatopi samādhi bhāvito ahosi.
mn128:32.1.eng: When I had developed immersion in these ways,

mn128:32.2.eng: the knowledge and vision arose in me:

mn128:32.3.pli: akuppā me cetovimutti. Ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
mn128:32.3.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

mn128:32.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn128:32.5.pli: Attamano āyasmā anuruddho bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn128:32.5.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Anuruddha approved what the Buddha said.
